I believe this will raise RowNotFound now instead of KeyError

Hmm, I don't understand one thing. What if:
1) In L984 there is no updated_at key (the utcnow() is taken)
2) What if the check in L988 is False
3) Then check in L997 is True and it the whole agent_alive() returns True,

So that means if we have Chassis entry, that has not the valid key set in the external_ids, and has not the valid Chassis.nb_cfg value set then we return that the agent is alive? But why?
This isn't a test of "it is currently really dead". It is a test of "hasn't been alive for X seconds". That's just how the agent API works unfortunately.

Hum, you're right. The only moment, where this key will not exist is when new ovn-controller is added to agent list. There shouldn't be any other use-case of that. So in those terms we should be same. +1

I still know that sooner or later this agent will be set as ':(' because in a few next iterations the check in L997 will be false.
But in meantime binding could be scheduled there, but actually ovn-controller will be dead, so I believe thats better to fix this use-case here.

We return that it is alive because it hasn't been dead long enough to be defined as dead by the configured agent_down_time. The only way we shouldn't have the the appropriate key is if this is the first time we are running.

Q question: Is there a situation where the agent's gone from the OVSDB but still in the cache ? I think there might be (in case someone manually delete the entry in SBDB.

I would make this method a bit more resilient to this type of error by doing the following:

try:
    get_agent(...)
except AgentNotFound:
    AGENTS.pop(id, None)
    raise

What do you think ?

We don't actually support deleting agents at this point at all. We only check get_agent here so that tests pass (send a 404 for non-existent agent) and we purposely keep the agents in the in-memory cache so that if ovn-controller is gracefully, but temporarily, stopped the agents don't just disappear instead of reporting as down.

So it seems like having a side-effect on the delete_agent call of removing the cache entry when we don't support actually removing agents would be a little weird. Am I misunderstanding?

My reasoning was because we could delete an agent by deleting them from the Chassis table in the Southbound database (maybe it was just an workaround).

Now it won't work because get_agents() is using the items from the cache. 

Not a big deal, just wanted to point out that we may want to get rid of the agent entry if it has been deleted from the SBDB.

neutron/privileged/agent/linux/ip_lib.py.message:
This is a magic, but it looks required to ensure "value" to be a string.

In python2, decode converts a string to a unicode string and str() converts a unicode string to a string.

In python3, decode() converts a byte string to a string and str() does nothing.

That's the point. In py2 I always have strings and this step is not needed. In py3 I can have bytes that need to be converted to str().

I'll add a TODO: In PY3, str() conversion is not needed and six.binary_type can be replaced with bytes.
nit: I think it's deprecated even now. Here should be "once support for PY2 is dropped"
Not deprecated yet - I believe that happens when https://pythonclock.org/ reaches zero - but your wording is better.  But I think anyone coming along will understand what is meant, so LGTM.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ku.message: These should be declared as constants since its referenced multiple times
If the caller passes in something other than a dict, shouldn't this throw an exception?
It's unlikely that the passed variable is not dict from top level and in case it's not a dict, it will return as is. But I have updated to raise the exception anyway. Same as below.
If the caller passes in something other than a dict, shouldn't this throw an exception?

This is OK, but in the future, if your method specifies that a parameter must be a dict, there is no need to check that. If a caller passes anything other than a dict, it is a coding error and would trigger an exception at the first point the code attempts to use the parameter as a dict. This would be caught at coding/testing time and shouldn't happen at runtime. To make a long story short, you could leave out this code and you would still get an exception which would be perfectly acceptable (and less code).

Right, the test is there to validate the code, not prove that it's necessary or a good idea. If something else breaks, then that's something to discuss but just the unit test that validates that it's doing what we know it's doing is obviously going to have to change.

obj.get(key, None) avoids a lazy-load, so there's a reason why we do that in places.

However, I think we should probably remove this line entirely. When it was originally added, it was a direct-to-db update call. When I converted all of those to object actions, there was an "instance.save()" below to immediately update the device name in the database. That was removed in a sweeping attempt to remove a bunch of extra instance.save() calls here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/119622

I think that the author and reviewers of that probably missed the nuance that _get_guest_config() is called in many places other than just during instance boot.

That said, I think that (a) it's pretty bad to put something that modifies the instance at all in a "get xml" method that a caller would have every expectation did not have any side-effects and (b) it probably has some very weird behavior now, dirtying the instance but only getting persisted if that instance object happens to be .save()d somewhere after this.

As far as I can tell we always set instance.root_device_name from the build_resources() chain during spawn() in compute manager (at least for libvirt, which is what this is for). I would argue that we should probably just remove this obscure side effect instead of making it more obscure in an attempt to whack-a-mole the symptom experienced in the bug.

Does anyone know of a reason *not* to just remove this?

The Ignition format is a json not yaml. So I think current code can handle case like {"ignition": {"version": "3.0.0"}, "storage": {}}. Unless the user is passing in something like:

> What is bad about the assumption?

It will fail with a very obscure error that means nothing to the user (something like "AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'setdefault'") if there is another type there.

Since this is being passed as yaml, it's very easy to trigger. e.g. this would fail with the error above:

    ignition:
      version: 3.0.0
    storage:
    passwd:
      users: []

> What do you propose doing instead?

Overwrite whatever is there if it is not a dict.

> The Ignition format is a json not yaml.

This is true, but it's being passed through a Heat template, so there's nothing to stop you writing yaml directly in the template.

There are 2 scenarios: 
This scenario handles the situation when the network is assigned to DHCP and the DHCP agent goes down.
But if you have a network which is assigned a DHCP agent ( in an env which has several  agents) and you unmap the network from the agent, it is rescheduled to another DHCP agent  by the DHCP Scheduler.schedule() . That is not required if you have a network which provides DHCP from its backend.

I observed this problem, that if we have a network without DHCP enabled on the subnet, it was still having a map with the DHCP agent. Using Vanilla Openstack. I have also linked the bug which has been created with the similar issue

I think, we should evaluate a bearable port quantity for one single ovs-agent. For instance, if a ovs-agent clould host 1000 ports (as far as I'm concerned it can't now), then its RPC, restart time, restart success rate, flow recovery are all at very high success rate, 99%?

Yes, there are definitely scale issues with the OVS agent and we don't want to overburden it. My thinking is that this shouldn't require an extra RPC call, all the information needed will be included in the response from the call to get_device_details(). At a minimum it takes the RPC round-trip to obtain the relevant information out of the mix. Of course there are issues processing large numbers of ports outside of the RPC context, so adding another call to OVS for each port is a valid concern.

I like this idea. In the past we seem to have simply measured the number of ports that can be serviced in aggregate across a region and how many compute nodes can be run, but even that isn't well documented. I think we can do a better job providing scale numbers, and this is a multi-faceted thing. I have a performance section in the latest patch set that is just a placeholder, we should capture what the current limits are there and compare with OVN.

That is a good point, we would need to consider how to provide the DNS functionality of dnsmasq somehow. Maybe it's easier to simply run dnsmaq locally and steer DHCP and DNS appropriately to a namespace? One of the overarching goals for me is to consolidate the number of agents that need to be run and monitored on any given node, pushing as much as possible into OVS. The DHCP agent seems like a prime candidate for consolidation, but maybe this is just not feasible. Nothing is ever really agentless, but fewer agents is simpler to operate and is a noble goal IMO.
Yes, but please keep in mind that ovs agent in current state is already not scale well. So giving him more and more work to do may kill it ;)

This is really a good proposal. But it may face some new problem, and I do not see any discuss in the previous context (maybe have discussed somewhere I just not see).
1. How to limit such distributed SNAT traffic? One router can spread to many compute hosts, then the SNAT functionality will work on it. Each router will have unlimited SNAT total bandwidth, since it is totally distributed. This can be a disaster when the users' VMs are hijacked, in a large public cloud, this can happen.
2. It will share the physical external device (we can not afford a new NIC for SNAT only, it costs too much), so it will have influence on floating IP traffic?
3. It will increase the operation difficulty?

Some concern that may arise in real production use, but do not hinder the advantages of this proposal.

I have talked to operators who love and hate this idea, and each have their own unique reasons. My proposal is provide the option for distributed SNAT, understanding that this isn't a one-size-fits-all solution.

1. This is a tricky problem, although it's one that exists when VM's with floating IP's get hijacked so I don't see it as a show-stopper for developing or deploying distributed SNAT. My thought is to make this something operators opt in to, so it's not forced on them.

2. Yes, SNAT would share the same external device as floating IP traffic. Ultimately in many deployments FIP, SNAT, and directly routable traffic is all funneled through the same top-of-rack gear and physical devices. The question is whether it is encapsulated in the overlay or not upon cloud ingress/egress. I don't see this as a blocker to deployments, it's just something to be aware of and consider developing QoS-like knobs for operators.

3. In what ways are you thinking this is more difficult to operate? That's a very subjective thing that depends on the environment. One thing I can think of that becomes more difficult when you distribute services like this is IDS/IPS, you simply have more points to worry about inspecting traffic. I've been a part of compliance reviews where this is a concern but nothing was a show-stopper. Perhaps extending tap-as-a-service or something similar would help some segment of operators?

This would not be possible, since we are sharing the FIP agent gateway port will all tenants.
So we need to come up with an External IP for each and every tenant per compute node in here.

I actually think it is possible, you can snat coming out of the qrouter namespace, then do it again on egress from the FIP namespace. Not elegant, but it works.

This is a place where openflow DVR may provide a cleaner solution, we wouldn't have the same multi-tenancy concerns there while processing the packet in an OpenFlow pipeline. There are commercial SDN solutions that do this exact thing with OpenFlow and OVS.

1) Why move OVN in-tree?

2) How will reviews work?

It's similar to how we had done things in Neutron for a while, with Lieutenants responsible for certain areas.  Over time this could change as people become more familiar with all the code.  It has the side-effect of growing the core team.

3) Gating

The number of gate jobs will initially grow, so we would need to look at reducing them somehow over the U cycle.  Time for linuxbridge deprecation?

4) Installers

We would have to figure out a packaging strategy, but I think we could keep things somewhat similar to today.  Upgrades is probably the more difficult piece.

While this sounds good on paper and from the point of view of a hypervisor getting rid of its traffic as soon as possible, it is important to think about the implications of doing so for the physical data center network.

In any data center you will find that there is only two or three physical locations where traffic enters or exits through border gateways. The traffic has to be transported there somehow.

OVN and networking-ovn has an elegant solution to this today where only chassis with proper bridge mappings are selected for gateway routers.  This way you can enable all chassis which are actually located in the vicinity of your border gateways to act as gateways.  The chassis located elsewhere do not need direct connection to the external network, as they will tunnel any external traffic to a chassis that acts as a gateway.  This plays nicely with Layer3-only data center fabrics (as exemplified by RFC 7938).

And please note that the chassis acting as gateways are of course not dedicated to this purpose, they still host instances and do other work as every other node in the cluster.

As it stands this behavior of OVN and networking-ovn is a huge gain over the existing ML2/OVS DVR solution, so please do not loose that in merging the projects.

The current Neutron ML2/OVS DVR setup offloads this job to the physical network by requiring every hypervisor in the cluster to have direct external connectivity.

The only way for the physical network to cope with it is to either create a globally shared Layer2 network for external connectivity or configure tunneling on the physical network equipment.  Neither of these solutions are desirable.

Example on Centos:

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
A (very quick and casual) audit suggests that none of the following compute host instance operations take an instance lock:

start
soft_delete
restore
rebuild
reboot
backup
snapshot
set_admin_password
inject_file
rescue
unrescue
revert_resize
resize
pause
unpause
suspend
resume

I believe this means they can all race on the compute host with delete. Several of these are highly likely to have undesirable interactions. I suggest locking them all might be in order.

How about an @instance_lock decorator in compute manager, applied across the board?

doc/source/_extra/.htaccess.message: Hm, I didn't think you could use anchors in a 301. Maybe I'm thinking of something else.

Not that I really expect anyone to deem it worth the effort, but I opened [1] to make `whereto` understand [codes] so we could theoretically "fix" this.

[1] https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2006943

Seems like we should make our check bounce on these.

[Later] Started digging here. For one thing...

 > Looks like you can't:
 > 
 > https://8625b4dd610148b27eaa-d80096115414d153e5879467e4fa5025.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/695779/1/check/openstack-tox-docs/b040620/docs/admin/manage-users.html

The CI build doesn't appear to process the redirects at all (e.g. the one above [1] also 404s).

According to documentation, .htaccess *would* normally break on this, because it encodes special characters. But it looks like you can add [NE] to the rule to make that not happen [2], which ought to mean you can successfully redirect to the anchor by doing that.

Unfortunately, we wouldn't be able to tell if it worked until the docs are published :(

[Later later] And also it looks like the `whereto` helper isn't set up to understand those codes:

 ValueError: Could not understand rule ('redirectmatch', '301', '^/nova/([^/]+)/admin/manage-users.html$', '/nova/$1/admin/arch.html#projects-users-and-roles', '[NE]')

...so we would have to fix that up first and bump our reqs.

[1] https://8625b4dd610148b27eaa-d80096115414d153e5879467e4fa5025.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/695779/1/check/openstack-tox-docs/b040620/docs/admin/port_with_resource_request.html
[2] http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/rewrite/flags.html#flag_ne

Looks like you can't:

https://8625b4dd610148b27eaa-d80096115414d153e5879467e4fa5025.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/695779/1/check/openstack-tox-docs/b040620/docs/admin/manage-users.html

So I'm not sure what to do with this - just redirect back to admin/index.html?

Yeah.

All those people with a bookmark are just going to have to scroll down.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: the fix seems legit, but I think we should provide a nice comment explaining that since we have some in-memory triggrer that makes sure that we can only cleanup once the instance events, we need to recreate that trigger for the specific case of SIGHUP where the module is still running.

Basically when nova-compute receives a SIGUP the "cleanup_host()" method is called. Which will cancel all "in-flight" events and block any new by setting self.instance_events to nil. I've added a clarifying comment. Hope that helps.

Yeah, I definitely don't understand why this is legit. What about a SIGHUP makes waiting events no longer operable? AFAICT, if we have any instances blocked on boot waiting for neutron events, then do a SIGHUP, even if the event arrives, it won't be delivered and then the waiting thread will just time out and fail.

SIGHUP does not cause manager.stop() to be run, so I'm not sure what this link has to do with anything. Service.reset() calls self.manager.reset() which is this method. Why do you think Service.stop() gets called? If it did, it would be severing all RPC connections and causing any in-flight operations from the API to fail, which is kindof exactly what SIGHUP is supposed to be doing (i.e. a very graceful warm reload of some things).

If something else is making us stop() and restart, that's a problem.

nova/tests/functional/test_cross_cell_mi.message:
This is intermittently failing here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/56fef7c0e74d7512f062c4046def10401df16565/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L528

Because it's saying host2 is not found:

    b'2019-05-08 17:22:12,138 WARNING [nova.scheduler.utils] Failed to compute_task_migrate_server: No valid host was found. No such host - host: host2 node: host2 '

I think it might be because of this code in the cold migration task before hitting the scheduler:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/56fef7c0e74d7512f062c4046def10401df16565/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L163

That sets the RequestSpec.requested_destination.cell to the source cell (cell1 for host1), and then the scheduler utility code uses that to try and find the destination host:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/56fef7c0e74d7512f062c4046def10401df16565/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L504

so in that case, target_cell is cell1 but target_host is host2 (in cell2) so that's why we fail to find it. Looks like resources_from_request_spec needs to not pass target_cell to get_compute_nodes_by_host_or_node if RequestSpec.requested_destination.allow_cross_cell_move=True since the target host could be in another cell.
It would be even better if the weigher is configured to prefer host3 over host2
